resources.string: Waste segregation helps keep the environment clean by reducing pollution and making recycling more effective. By separating waste properly, you prevent harmful materials from mixing with recyclables, reduce landfill waste, and conserve natural resources. So what are you waiting for? Be a part of the solutionâ€”start segregating today!
The model was trained using hyperparameters like epochs, learning rate, and batch size to improve accuracy. A confusion matrix was used to evaluate performance and ensure correct classification.

Integrated into this app as a tensorflow lite format, the model helps users identify waste types instantly, promoting proper waste disposal. Future updates will improve accuracy and add more waste categories to enhance sustainability efforts.

Biodegradable waste is material that breaks down naturally through microorganisms and environmental factors, such as food scraps, dry leaves, and organic waste. This process helps reduce environmental impact and can contribute to climate protection through recycling.

Non-biodegradable waste refers to materials that cannot be broken down or decomposed by natural biological processes. These wastes, such as plastics, metals, and glass, remain in the environment for long periods, potentially causing harm to ecosystems. Unlike biodegradable waste, non-biodegradable waste does not return to the earth and requires alternative methods of disposal or recycling.

Recyclable waste refers to materials that can be collected, processed, and transformed into new products instead of being disposed of in landfills. Common recyclable materials include paper, glass, plastic, and metal, which can be reused after undergoing a recycling process to reduce environmental impact and conserve resources.

Electronic waste (e-waste) refers to discarded electronic devices and equipment, such as computers, phones, and televisions, that are no longer in use or intended for reuse. This type of waste includes a wide range of items with electrical components or circuitry, often containing hazardous materials. Proper disposal and recycling of e-waste are essential to reduce environmental impact and recover valuable materials.

Helping you sort waste efficiently for a sustainable future. Together, we make a difference! By sorting and recycling waste effectively, we free our planet from pollution and open the door to a healthier, greener, and more sustainable world for all.
Proper waste management empowers individuals and communities by reducing environmental burdens, promoting sustainability, and creating opportunities for a cleaner future.

ECOSORT, your guide to efficient waste segregation! To use the app, simply open it, point your camera at the object you want to classify, and tap the Scan button. It will quickly identify and categorize the item into one of five categories: Biodegradable, Non-Biodegradable, Recyclable, or Electronic Waste. Once classified, follow the recommended disposal method for responsible waste management!

Organic waste refers to biodegradable materials that naturally decompose, such as food scraps, yard trimmings, and other plant-based materials. When these materials end up in landfills, they often cannot break down properly due to poor ventilation, temperature, and humidity, which can lead to the production of harmful gases like methane. Proper disposal or composting of organic waste helps recycle nutrients back into the environment and reduces environmental impact.

1. Gather vegetable peels, fruit peels, eggshells, and similar organic waste in a separate container. 2. Avoid mixing organic waste with plastics, paper, glass, or other non-biodegradable materials. 3. Place the organic waste in a biodegradable bag or a green bin labeled for organic waste. 4. If you have space, use the organic waste to create compost by placing it in a compost bin or pile and adding dry materials like dried leaves. 5. Do not throw organic waste into canals, rivers, or open areas to prevent pollution and flooding. 6. Ensure the organic waste is properly stored in covered bins to avoid attracting pests. 7. Coordinate with your local waste management service to have the organic waste collected on designated days. 8. If composting is not possible and collection services are unavailable, contact the local government for proper disposal instructions.
